The ND Clause⬤

Copyright (c) [Year] [Licensor]

The ND Clause License 1.0

The software, in source, binary, or other forms, is provided to you under the Base License subject to the following clauses:

A) The grant of rights under the Base License will not include, and this license does not grant to you, the right to publish or distribute derivative works of this software, or otherwise make them publicly available.

B) Clause A shall not apply to derivative works which are included into the source form of this software, and shall not apply to those which have existed for no greater than six weeks since their first public availability.

C) Clause A terminates on the Change Date, or the sixth anniversary of the first publicly available distribution of the software, whichever is earlier. Thereafter, you are granted full rights set forth in the Base License.

D) This license and the copyright notice above shall be included in each original or modified copy of the source form of the software.

For the purpose of clauses above only, and notwithstanding the Base License, the definition of "derivative works" shall not include works that link or bind by name to the interface of the software and are not otherwise based upon the software.

Everyone is permitted to copy and distribute verbatim copies of this license, but modification is not permitted.

Change Date: [yyyy-mm-dd]

Base License: [e.g. MIT License]

FAQ#

General understanding | Complying with the license | Using the license | Miscellaneous

General understanding#

What is ND Clause License?#

It is a parameterized license that adds additional clauses on top an existing license, i.e. the Base License.

Those additional clauses restrict the right to make derivative works of the covered software publicly available in a certain period of time, without restricting other rights and conditions in the Base License. After that time period, terms in the Base License becomes fully applicable to the software.

For usage, please see How do I apply this license to my software.

Is this an open source license, assuming the Base License is one?#

No. Clause A restricts the public availability of derivative works in a certain period of time as specified in clause C. This restriction, though not permanent, does not meet the established definition of Open Source. Some may categorize the license as a Source Available license.

Must I use an open source license as the Base License?#

It's not necessary. Though the "Build a license" section only displays a number of common choices, you can manually fill the Base License blank with any license.

Does the license grant copyright and patent rights, etc.?#

It all depends on the Base License. The additional clauses here only deal with some aspects of the derivative works.

What is the "source form"?#

It means the preferred form in which developers make changes to the software, including but not limited to:

  • Source code, including but not limited to code used to compile, transform, test, release, and deploy.
  • Configuration files.
  • Other text, image, or multimedia files.

What are other forms beside the source form?#

There are forms resulting from mechanical transformation of the source form, including but not limited to binary (in its narrow meaning), compiled, minimized, annotated or otherwise processed code, generated documentations, as well as conversions to other media types.

The license refrained from covering these with a simple "binary form" or "object form", because the transformation output might not be "binaries" in its narrow meaning. For example, barely-human-readable JavaScript from a JavaScript minimizer or a TypeScript compiler.

What are typical examples of a "derivative work" of the software, according to the definition employed by clause A?#

The following are all examples of creating a derivative work:

  • Copy ("fork") the source form of a software then add, delete, or otherwise modify that source.
  • Rewrite the software in another programming language.
  • Make T-shirts with pictures derived from the software's logo.

Why make the exception that linking or binding by name is not a criterion of determining if a work is a "derivative work"?#

Copyright laws generally don't consider a work W is a derivative work simply by the fact that W links or otherwise binds by name to the interface of software S. However, there are some confusions around this topic, especially some may assume GNU GPL's stance is that linking—static or dynamic—results in a derivative work. The explicit exception in this license made it clear.

Note the exception does not apply to the phrase of "derivative work" in the Base License, which may have its own interpretation.

Complying with the license#

Can I copy ("fork") a software that uses the license?#

Yes, on the condition that you comply with the Base License. Clause A does not limit the creation of an exact copy ("fork"). Instead, it deals with issues related to derivative works.

Can I create derivative works of a software that uses the license?#

Yes, on the condition that you comply with the Base License. Clause A does not limit creation of derivative works, but public availability thereof.

Can I distribute derivative (or otherwise make publicly available) works of a software that uses the license?#

Only if you comply with the Base License and meet one of the following conditions, the answer is "yes":

  • The derivative work is included to the source code of the software within 6 weeks since the day on which derivative work becomes publicly available for the first time,
  • The current date is on or after the date specified in clause C.

For example, assuming the date specified in clause C has not arrived and the Base License permits, you are allowed by the license to copy ("fork") the software's source code without making changes. If you do make any changes, you must either (1) successfully let the change be included to the software source (i.e. make a contribution) within 6 weeks since its first public availability, or (2) make your change not publicly available.

What if I want to contribute my change back to the software source, but the contribution was not accepted?#

In this case, you must make the change not publicly available until the date specified in clause C.

For example, if the said derivative work is on an online platform that provides code hosting services (e.g. GitHub), and your contribution was not included into the source form of the software, you must either (1) delete the code containing the derivative work, or (2) make the said code repository private, until the date specified in clause C.

Though appearing to be rough, the clauses were designed this way to prevent a hypothetical scenario where someone made a disingenuous attempt to contribute their modified version back, knowing it wouldn't be accepted, but in fact that attempt was made just in order to work around clause A.

Naturally, this requirement is discouraging to genuine contributors, but it seems there's no other way. ☹

If I successfully contributed my change back to the software source, do I need to make my own copy ("fork") not publicly available afterwards?#

There is no need to, since according to clause B, clause A does not apply to derivative works that are included into the source form of this software—unless you made an additional change on top of that already-included change, because doing so results in a new derivative work, which subjects to the same terms just like the previous derivative work.

A software using the license has implemented some classes, from which classes in my new software inherit. Is my software a "derivative work" in clause A?#

Class inheritance is neither a necessary nor a sufficient condition for creating derivative works. A judge will decide on the specifics.

A child class does acquire functionalities from its base class(es) via inheritance (subclassing). However, without specifics of the new software, this reason alone is not enough to determine whether the child class is a derivative work of the base class. Otherwise, all Java softwares would be considered derivative works of the Java language implementation since, in Java, any class ultimately inherits from the generic Object class.

The same answer applies to other ways of writing new code that acquires existing functionalities, e.g. class composition and aggregation.

A software using the license has a plugin interface. I wrote a plugin for it using the interface, and beyond that the plugin did not modify or otherwise adapt code from the software. Is the plugin a "derivative work" in clause A?#

The plugin in question only binds by name to the interface of the software, so it is not a derivative work under the definition applicable to clause A, according to the exception made clear in the license.

Using the license#

How do I apply this license to my software?#

The recommended way to do so is:

First, create a file named LICENSE.txt at the root of your code repository, and copy the license template given above, with Change Date and Base License indicated, then (highly recommended) followed by the content of the Base License, for example: 

Copyright (c) [Year] [Name]

The ND Clause License X.Y
...(full text of license)...
Change Date:  YYYY-MM-DD
Base License: XYZ License

Base License, as part of the license above:

XYZ License
...(full text of license)...

Then, mention your LICENSE.txt in your README file and/or the project's site.

Finally, though optional, declare at the beginning of every source file that the content is subject to this license, so that if your file gets copied into another software, your license information is not lost. For example in C++, 

// Copyright (c) [Year] [Name]. All rights reserved.
// Use of this file is governed by the ND Clause License in LICENSE.txt.

Can I copy the license and modify its wording (e.g. change or remove "six weeks", "sixth anniversary")?#

Nope.

The license text made it clear that [e]veryone is permitted to copy and distribute verbatim copies of this license, but modification is not permitted. So you can't change it in anyway, not even a punctuation.

Can I use only some paragraphs of the license text?#

Nope.

Every part of the license text is an integral part of the license itself. The license text made it clear that [e]veryone is permitted to copy and distribute verbatim copies of this license, but modification is not permitted.

Why does the license forbid modifying the license text itself?#

One of the reasons is to prevent proliferation of licenses with similar but different terms. This situation confuses people greatly.

Can I translate the license text into another language?#

Yes. However, in order to prevent discrepancies, any translated text is informal and is not legally binding. Though not fair, at present English is the de facto common language used by developers to communicate across the world.

It is recommended the original text be copied into the license notice along side any translated text, and statement be made explicitly only the original is legally binding.

I published a software under the license. Can I modify the Change Date or Base License afterwards?#

The parameters are integral parts of the entire license, so tweaking them is the same as changing the license (relicensing).

Generally, laws require consensus among all copyright holders in order to have a license change. It is legally and technically challenging to do so for a software that has many copyright holders. Also note the new license does not apply to prior versions of the software; the original license still applies to them.

If authors have not assigned—not merely licensed—the copyrights to their contributed patches to others, then all of them are copyright holders of the software, unless their contributions were removed. Contrary to what many people have assumed, software licenses do not stipulate making contributions implies copyright assignments; after all, they are "licensing agreements". In most cases, a signed agreement with the contributor is necessary to effectuate a copyright assignment.

The above is not legal advice; bring a lawyer familiar with your situation.

Miscellaneous#

Why not just use Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivatives (CC BY-ND)?#

Creative Commons licenses are not suitable for software, according to the the FAQ page on the Creative Commons website.

In fact, "ND" in the name of this license, which stands for NoDerivatives, was initially inspired by CC BY-ND. However, unlike CC BY-ND, this license does not put a blanket ban on distribution of all derivative works (which would make contribution back to the software impossible), and does not make the said ban permanent.

Why did you make this license?#

Some excellent works don't get published because the authors feared the works could be forked into oblivion (think forking and re-releasing a nascent browser extension just for the sake of it), and in other cases factional dissidence may turn bitter in a project.

This license attempts to raise the speed bump slightly higher to put their mind at ease, by encouraging thoughtful contribution and conversation, rather than whimsical bifurcation and division. After all, closing source is strictly worse.

That being said, clause A and B in combination only restricts a certain aspect of the Base License, and that restriction terminates on the date specified in clause C, by which time the software, not one of its forks, has hopefully gained enough recognition to be thought as the one true source.

There are pros and cons. This license is just an option on the table.

I think the license does not conform to the ideal of Open Source.#

As mentioned earlier, this license does not meet the established definition of Open Source, and does not seek the recognition of being one.

This license provides an option on the table for those on the fence. You are welcome to choose another license for your project.
